THE NEWS-LETTER.
VOL. VII.

MAY 7, 1903.

No. 14.

THE GULF BIOLOGICAL STATION.

t

HE want of a biological station on the Gulf of Mexico has long been felt
by American biologists. Until recently no laboratory for the study of
marine biology existed south of Beaufort, North Carolina, although
our southern waters are extremely rich in animal and plant life. So attractive
have been the reports of visitors to the Gulf coast, that a strong desire for a
permanent station has been created, and the United States Fish Commission
has for several years been contemplating the advisableness of gratifying it by
erecting a laboratory on the Florida coast. At present also, the naturalists of
the country are interested in an independent project to establish a station on
the Tortugas. Both of these enterprises have been anticipated by the inauguration of the "Gulf Biologic Station," by the State of Louisiana.
The Louisiana station is located in the south-western extremity of Cameron
Parish, on a point where the Calcasieu River opens into the Gulf. It is about
a day's sail from Galveston, Texas, and 280 miles from New Orleans. The
town of Cameron, two miles inland from the laboratory, is a small settlement
of 150 people. The isolation which is thus secured is one of the summer needs
of the biologist, who, during this period, must be freed from the conventions of
civilized life.
The environment of Cameron is conducive to work—apparently there is
nothing else to do. Northward, east and west, extend the alluvial plains, in
regions thickly wooded, but often bounded only by the horizon. The local
'mango' gives these stretches of shere flatness, somewhat of a roughened edge,
while here and there a decided nick is produced in the sky by a clump of larger
trees. The vastness of these plains gives one the feeling of being alone in a
great solitude. Surely this is the place where that strange desire which many
men feel at sometime of their lives—to shout and not be heard—can be gratified.
Even here disappointment lies in wait. A shout would startle the cattle
cropping peacefully the miles of pasture; they would cock their ears and look
with surprise in the direction of the noise. Some of the more inquisitive ones
would start off at a lively canter, kicking up their hind legs and prancing as
only cows with glad hearts can. In those regions they do not hear a noise
every day of their lives.
South-east, south and south-west, lie the chief interests of the station.
There are the problems in the solution of which Louisiana makes the first state
contribution to research in marine biology.
The campaign begins this summer. The work to be undertaken will include
a study of the best way to develop scientific methods of oyster culture, and a
general biological survey of the Gulf of Mexico. The prevailing South-east
•

2

THE NEWS LETTER.

winds bring to shore many of the pelagic forms with which the Gulf stream is
alive, but the whole mountain does not come to Mahomet.
To meet this difficulty a launch and a sharpy are to be provided. With
these boats extensive dredgings will be made on the flat extending outward from
the coast, and localities will be plotted and marked. Such animals as do not
float ashore or which are too small to be picked up, will be gathered by means
of the surface net which is towed through the water behind a slowly moving
boat. This method of collecting is particularly successful on quiet nights at
high tide. Then the larvx and other small pelagic animals rise to the surface
and can easily be scooped up in large quantities. Their presence in the net is
betrayed by a dim glow. At Beaufort, on very dark still nights, the water is so
crowded with living things, that the course of a boat is marked by flashes of
blinding brilliancy, and in rowing, showers of living sparks drip from the oars.

Besides the Fauna and Flora of the Gulf itself, the student finds much to
interest him on land. Lining the rivers and bayous, are large pecan trees and
live oaks, black and rugged, hut with a tinge of sadness, for the pendant
streamers of the gray Spanish moss lend them the appearance of weeping willows.
The 'mango' grows everywhere, and from its joints spring forth the golden tufts
of the parasitic dodder.
Tropical fruits abound throughout the parish.
Oranges grow in every garden, and lemons, olives, figs and bananas attract no
more attention than our apples and pears,

THE NEWS LETTER.

a

Most attractive of all the land animals are the birds. Wild ducks and
gees live in the marshes whefe they probably feed on the eggs and young of
the diamond back terrapin. Cranes and herons patrol the shores, and the rice
bird hovers about the bushes preparatory to its disastrous flight to the north.
Along the Gulf shore, the jack snipe struts about with nervous jerk, and the
egret, blinding with whiteness, can be seen for miles. As if to set off the beauty
of this bird, the black ominous water-turkey, clumsy of flight, wobbles by, low
on the water. Most conspicuous of all however are the flocks of brown pelican.
These use for a roosting place the great stone jetties that project out to sea
for two miles from the mouth of the Calcasieu. River. Here they sit in straight
dignified rows as though taking a lesson. Suddenly however, they become restless, and in a moment, with legs stretched out stiffly behind, they are off to sea
in an irregular squad, which at last is visible only as a group of small, uncertain
specks. When they are on the verge of disappearing, these specks, momentarily
at rest, suddenly grow larger again, and the return flight begins, this time not in
a squad, but spread out like a thin line of heroes,' until they reach the jetty,
where after considerable disorder, they once more sit motionless in a very
correct row.
The life at a marine laboratory, however remote, is far from dull and anything but conventional. It is too full of activity to be the one and too unusual
to be the other. For the men who spend their vacations at a sea-side station,
work is a source of endless pleasure, and they who can experience the delight of
finding out something new, are amply repaid for all sacrifices. While it sometimes happens that a whole night is 'spent in watching a series of developing
eggs, and that meals are brought to the work table, more often the days pass
with a healthy mixture of indoor and outdoor work. The latter nearly always
means a few hours' run on the launch, a sail—time of return is never mentioned--a walk on the beach, and probably a dip in the surf.
These collecting trips, even when resulting in no particular find, are never
without good effect, for the exertion, the excitement and sometimes the risk call
into play all the powers of body and .mind, and bring about the tingle that
always. accompanies the healthful expenditure of superfluous energy.
Then
too, the community of interests makes good cheer and the air is blue with songs,
stories and puns. Even university professors, tight-laced with dignity, learning
and fame, do not hesitate to smoke a corn-cob pipe and to take off their shoes
and stockings when necessary.. A crowd of biologists coming back from a
moonlight towing would, in a city, be arrested for disturbing the peace.
THE DEBATE WITH NORTH CAROLINA.
GAIN the Universii y of North Carolina has defeated us in debate ; but
the contest was even closer than last year, and the decision of the judges
was not unanimous. Then, too, Hopkins won a partial victory in that
the judges unanimously decided Plaggemeyer the best debater who took part
in the contest. Hopkins lost the debate because the North Carolina team excelled
•

4

4

THE NEWS LETTER.

in logical development and the completeness of their line of argument. In delivery the Hopkins men equalled or excelled their opponents.
The debate was held in Gerrard Hall in the presence of an audience composed largely of university professors and students. Governor Aycock, who
presided, announced the question, read the instructions to the judges, and then
called upon the secretary to announce the first speaker upon the affirmative side.
Mr. Solomon Blum, who opened the debate for Hopkins, was well received, and succeeded in making his points stand out clearly. Mr. S. S. Robins,
a junior at North Carolina, followed with a speech such as one hears upon the
floor of the United States Senate. The speech, which dealt largely with the development of governmental functions and the history of our merchant marine, was
delivered in a masterful manner. When Mr. Plaggemeyer had finished the
next speech for Hopkins, the advantage that Carolina had gained in her first
speech was largely overcome. Mr. R. 0. Everett, a senior, then delivered a
twenty-minute speech in which he still further developed the line of argument laid
down in Carolina's first speech. In the rejoinders the extemporaneous speeches
of Messrs. Blum, Robins and Everett demonstrated the ability of those men to
think quickly and to present their arguments clearly without previous preparation. But Plaggemeyer's rebuttal was by far the most effective speech of the
evening. Plag. was at his best and he carried his audience with him in a way that
surprised even those who have heard him in former debates. When he finished
speaking, it was any one's victory. As it was, the decision proved to be a victory
for Plaggemeyer as well as for the University of North Carolina.
While the judges were deliberating, Governor Aycock responded to the repeated demonstrations of the Carolina students. He said that, in his opinion, the
judges had to decide the old question:—"What happens when an irresistable force
meets an immovable body." During the debate, the Governor said his convictions had been reinforced and his faith destroyed four times that he awaited the
decision of the judges in order that he might know whether he must forsake the
traditions of his childhood, or be permitted to die in the faith.
After the Governor had ceased speaking, the Carolina students in the gallery called for Strayer, the alternate of the Hopkins team, who expressed, on
behalf of the team, their appreciation of the hospitality which they had enjoyed.
When the decision had been announced and congratulations had been exchanged,
a carriage conveyed the Hopkins men to the residence of Professor Gore, where
they were introduced to Governor Aycock, President Venable, the judges of the
debate, the professors and their wives, and many of the Carolina students who
are interested in debating. After they had enjoyed the collation provided, the
team returned to the hotel to get a few hours sleep before starting home. ,
The members of the Johns Hopkins party unite to express high appreciation
of their reception and entertainment at Chapel Hill. They all declare that their
personal acquaintance with the traditional cordiality and hospitality of Dixie
farther South has been most pleasantly enlarged.

TRUSTEES VISIT OTHER UNIVERSITIES.
will be remembered that at the Commemoration Day exercises, Preside
nt
Remsen, in speaking of Homewood, said that as many of the trustees as
could leave would go this Spring upon a tour of investigation to learn
what
other universities could teach them for the development
of the Homewood land.
Accordingly a party of the trustees, consisting of Dr. Remsen, Messrs.
R. Brent
Keyser, John Gill, Blanchard Randall, Lewis N. Hopkins, and
Eugene
Levering, visited the University of Virginia several weeks ago. They
were
cordially received and brought back many pleasant impressions of the
trip.
The University lands and buildings were inspected by them, and
they secured
many suggestions which will be helpful in the development of
Homewood.
In a few days, perhaps early next week, the trustees will visit
Columbia,
Princeton, University of Penna., Haverford and Bryn Mawr, with the
same
Purpose in view. Still later, at a time not yet determined upon, Harvar
d, Yale
and other Northern universitites will be made fields of further
study.
St.
Louis, too, may be visited, though the trustees are doubtful of this trip.
Washington University, the St. Louis institution now attracting the general
notice of
advanced educators in the United States, has now to deal with practically the
same problem that confronts Johns Hopkins. The university
has lately been
given a large plot of land, and the conditions of the gift are quite
similar to
those under which Homewood recently came into the possession of
Johns Hopkins. Washington, however, is more fortunate than Hopkins, since several
of
their buildings are erecting for the use of the approaching Louisia
na Purchase
Exposition, and at the close of the Exposition they will be turned over to the
University.
President Randall, of Washington, has written to Dr. Remsen
inviting the trustees to visit his University, and learn how their mutual proble
m
is met out there. The only thing that prevents the trustee
s from accepting the
invitation is the length of the trip to St. Louis, which would consume more
time than they feel able at present to give to it.
- The trouble to which the trustees are putting themselves to in order to have
the benefit of expert counsel is a guarantee that the final result will
be the best
that the most careful thought can devise. President Remsen, in speakin
g of
one of the most urgent needs of the University, an athletic field, gives
further
emphasis to this same purpose on the part of the University trustees.
He
seems to recognize quite fully the general desire on the part of undergraduates
,
and many of the graduate students and alumni, for an athletic field
that will be
Hopkins's own. The unsatisfactory and unprofitable shifts which the University
athletic teams are now obliged to make between Electric Park, Maryland Oval,
Druid Hill, and the city base ball park are probable quite as well understood
by
Dr. Remsen as by the managers of the teams themselves. The trustees,
indeed,
have even sought preliminary plans for an athletic field in advance of the other
developments of Homewood. With these plans in hand, however, it has seemed
wiser to them to stay the work, lest anything that might be done before the
general scheme of extension into "The Promised Land," has been decided by
mature judgment would have to be undone.

l g V its victory over Swarthmore on last Saturday, the University lacrosse
team is once more entitled to the proud distinction of being The Intercollegiate Champions of the United States." Winner of the championship
five times in six years is a record that would be hard to surpass. This year the
honor was not won without the hardest kind of work, and for this reason every
man connected with the team deserves all the more credit. At the beginning
of the season the chances for another championship team seemed slight indeed.
The loss of such lacrosse players as Abercrombie, Briscoe, Bernheim, Sayler, and
Captain Schmeisser seemed too great to be overcome, and predictions were made
that with the material on hand the University could not develop a first class
team for 1903. Nothing daunted, however, .Captain Straus and Coach Abercrombie set to work to develop a team that would stand comparison with those
of former • years. From the beginning the men were impressed with the fact
that steady, consistent work was absolutely necessary. The 1903 championship
banner that will soon be hung in the trophy room bears witness of their success.
Though the Intercollegiate lacrosse season is ended, there are some more
honors that the team is trying for, . On Saturday, the Crescents, the - Athletic

THE NEWS LETTER.
Champions of the United States, will play the University, and without question
the game will be one of the best seen in Baltimore for some time. The Crescents have not forgot their defeat two years ago, and according to report, are
going to bring to Baltimore some of the best lacrosse players in the country. The
University team is just as determined to win, and make the year an unbroken
line of victories.

HE joint concert of the Woman's College and the University Musical
Clubs to be given on Saturday night for the benefit of the Lawrence
House Mission, deserves the support of every Hopkins man. In another
column is given an account of how the mission carries on its work. Clearly an
object more worthy of the united assistance of all cannot be found. Since the
work done by the mission is very great, the opportunity for assisting in this work,
and at the same time being agreeably entertained, should be taken advantage of.
A number of students give practical aid to the mission by taking charge of classes.
However, this is not all that is needed; financial help is absolutely necessary to
continue the work. For this reason, the management hopes to have even a
larger attendance at the concert than last year, when a considerable sum was
turned over.

'l' length, after many months of hard work, the long-suffering editors of the
1903 Hullabaloo are ready to announce what will be the special feature.,
of their book. From their description, this "Hullabaloo" bids fair to be
one of the best and most interesting ever brought out by the students of the
university.
In the first place, the cover will be black and blue, divided diagonally,
with the class flag showing the class colors, olive and white, in one corner.
Another of Brook Levering's allegorical color-pieces is promised. The leader:
will be two in number, a departure from former "Hullabaloos"—the first by W.
W. Willoughby, Ph. D., Associate Professor of Political Science, the second by
Dr. E. L. R. Gould, Chamberlain of New York •City. The peculiarly interesting feature of these leaders is that they are articles in which specialists aro
speaking of their specialty—"talking shop," as it were.
The order of the classes is reversed, the Sub-freshmen coming first and the
Seniors last. In connection with the class lists, there are some amusing drawings
showing the progress from the innocence of the Sub-freshman to the dignity of the
Senior. The fraternity drawing is a striking one by McKee Barclay. The
members of the fraternities not having chapters at the University have been carefully and thoroughly worked up. An excellent idea in connection with Athletics
is that on the page opposite each team picture are the description and personnel
of the team. A complete and detailed list of all the "H's" and "H. A. A.'s"
of
in the university, has for the first time been compiled. As for the "stunts,"

Z.

S

THE NEWS LETTER.

--several pages are devoted to the opinions of the members of the class on things
in general (including "girls") and to the votes of the class on the various qualifications of certain of the members. These begin the "stunts" proper which
cover about sixty-seven pages.
However, the features of the book on which the board has worked hardest
and put forth its best efforts are the drawings of girls and the music. The
board has been fortunate in obtaining from several prominent New York artists
—C. Alan Gilbert, W. Granville-Smith, and others—drawings in which are
shown "Hopkins Girls," more charming and beautiful than their avowed worshipers could imagine. The best thing about these pictures is that they are distinctly not amateurish.
The Song Book, comprising eight songs with music, will make the "Hullabaloo" of especial interest to alumni,since the songs given are those which are and
have been most sung by University students. This Song Book is the first that
has'ever been published at the Hopkins, and it is hoped that this small beginning
may lead to better things in this line.
It is hoped by the editors that the "Hullabaloo" will be out by the 15th of
May, but this depends on Providence and the printers. In bringing out the
"Hullabaloo" the board has had a trouble with which former boards have not
been afflicted—they have had to solicit their advertisements, instead of the publisher taking charge of this side of the book. However, by the remarkable
push and ability of "Billy" Bird, this financially important feature has been excellently handled. In conclusion it is only necessary to say that the 1903 "Hullabaloo" will undoubtedly be a credit to Lanier, Tootle and the other members
of the editorial staff.

HULLABALOO ELECTIONS.
FTER long delay and extensive electioneering, the Junior class held a
meeting last Thursday to elect editors for the 1904 "Hullabaloo." It took
some time to elect the editor-in-chief and his assistnant, as the election of
these officers was fraught with much heat. The fitness of each nominee was proclaimed by his supporters with loud, plausible, and unconvincing arguments.
Finally, after considerable spirited .discussion, Reginald S. Opie was chosen
Of the
editor-in-chief, and Ralph 0. Fucrbringer, associate editor-in-chief.
ten candidates for the associate literary editors, the following were elected: G. A.
Foster, J. C. L. Hawkins, W. L. LeCron, H. S. Lloyd, C. H. Saylor, and Frank
Stollerwerck. Henry Evans was unanimously elected art editor. The Business Manager is J. L. Bennett; the assistant Business Managers are R. Gordon
Dulaney and Sydney C. Erlanger.
. It is to be hoped that the interest which the class has shown in these elections
is an earnest of the help which they will give the board next year in bringing
out a "Hullabaloo" which will be up to the standard set by the best of
its predecessors.

THE NEWS LETTER.
BALTIMORE'S NEXT MAYOR.

OHNS HOPKINS has developed her first mayor. She has entertained a
good many mayors at her publiic gatherings in the past, but never one of
her own. When the Hon. Robert M. McLane makes his bow at the
next commencement exercises, the distinguished assembly will be receiving the
salute of the member of the class of 1887. His salute will doubtless be returned
in the proper spirit.
Baltimore's mayor-elect prepared at Mr. Marston's School, entering the University in the Fall of 1884. He took the classical course, and during his entire
undergraduate career was a leader in his classes. From his Freshman year until
his graduation, Mr. McLane held honorary scholarships, and graduated with high
honors. He was, however, no "grind," but had the happy faculty of getting at
the gist of his studies without much work. In the eighties there were not so
many athletic teams as there are to-day, and Baltimore's mayor went for nothing
more strenuous than tennis, at which game he was a player of more than ordinary
ability. A gentleman who was at the University with Mr. McLane, says that he
enjoyed a good joke, and always had a ready line of stories, which he told in a
most entertaining manner. He was always one of the best dressed men about the
University. By many, Mayor McLane is remembered as a 'clean cut, faultlessly
dressed chap, who always had a pleasant smile, and a cheerful word for his companions, but who did not mingle much with them. In those days he cared little
for the society of women, a habit which seems never to have left him.
After leaving the University Mr. McLane followed the usual course of
studies suscribed by the Maryland University's faculty, and became a member of
the Baltimore bar. About four years ago he was elected State's Attorney on the
Democratic ticket. He now leaves the Criminal Court for the City Hall.

TURIN BULL LECTURES 1903 04.

The lectures on the Percy Turnbull Memorial Foundation for the academic
year 1903-04 will be given by Count Angelo de Gubernatis, Professor of Italian
Literature in the University of Rome.
The lectures will be eight or nine in number, and the subject will be the
"Poetry of the Italian Renaissance." The lecturer will speak in French.
Count de Gubernatis is Professor of Italian Literature in the University of
Rome; General Secretary of the Italian Oriental Academy; the author of numerous literary, historical, and dramatic works; Italian correspondent of the
Athenaeum and the Contemporary Review, London, the International Review,
Vermont, and other papers.

TI1E NEWS LETTER.
UNIVERSITY NOTES.

Dr. L. S. Hulbert, who has bccn ill with typhoid fever, is convalescing.
Dr. A. Marshall Elliott will sail in :June for the other, side, and will spend
the summer abroad.
Dr. Bower, of Washington, delivered a lecture in the Physical Laboratory,
Monday, April 27th, on "Terrestial Magnetism."
Dr. Bower also gave the
students interested in the subject a chance to pursue the actual experiments at
Fort McHenry.
Saturday, May 9th, Dr. Paul Haupt will sail from New York for England,
where he will visit Oxford and Cambridge, after which he will travel in Germany.
At the meeting of the National Academy of Sciences held in Washington,
April 22nd, President Remsen was elected vice-president of the Academy. Prof.
Simon Newcomb was elected foreign secretary to succeed President Remsen.
Prof. W. H. Welch was elected a member of the Academy council.
Dr. Norman MacLeod Harris, associate in bacteriology, has resigned from
the Medical School and has accepted a position as assistant to Dr. Jordan, professor of bacteriology at the University of Chicago.
At the meeting of the Eastern Teachers' Art Association, held in McCoy
Hall, an address of welcome was delivered by Dr. Geo. B. Shaddock. An attractive exhibit of tie work of the school children in several towns and cities
throughout the country was arranged in the main hall. The drawings called
forth much favorable comment from visitors.
Dr. Florence R. Sabin, an assistant in anatomy at the Medical School, has
won the prize of $1,000. offered two years ago by the Association for the Promotion of Scientific Research by Women. Dr. Sabin's paper is on the "Origin
of the Lymphatic System." Dr. Sabin received her M. D. at the Hopkins in 1900.
During her course she held the fellowship in anatomy, and after her graduation
she was appointed instructor. Recently, she was offered the professorship of
anatomy at the Woman's Medical College in London, but she declined, preferring
her present work at the Hopkins.
At a recent meeting of the American Institute. of Social Service, Mr. Robert
Garrett, Dr. Albert Shaw, and Dr. E. R. L. Gould were appointed members of
the American committee which is to co-operate with the sociological workers of
the other countries in the International Housing Congress, to be held in Paris,
from July to November next. The congress is to be under the patronage of the
French government. It will discuss the importance of inaugurating preventive
measures against the spread of tuberculosis and alcoholism..
At the meeting of the .M edical and Chirurgical Faculty, papers were read
by Drs. William H. Welch and Henry B. Jacobs. Dr. Welch spoke chiefly about
the methods employed in New York for the prevention of tuberculosis. Dr.
Jacobs read a paper on "Our Need of a Mountain Sanitarium for Indigent
Consumptives." Other papers were read by the following Hopkins men: Drs.
W. S. Baer, T. R. Brown, H. O. Reik and S. R. Hirshberg. Professor R. W.
Wood also delivered a lecture on "Colored Photography."
•

THE NEWS LETTER.

11

Dr. Harry C. Jones has recently begun a series of weekly lectures on advanced inorganic chemistry from the physical standpoint.
The lectures are
along the line laid down in his "Principles of Inorganic Chemistry," published
several months ago.
Dr. Norman MacD. Harris, associate in bacteriology, has revised and edited
an American edition of the "Manual of Bacteriology," by Doctors Muir and
Ritchie. The book is published by the Macmillian Co.
Dr. Gamgee, the distinguished professor of physiology at Owens College,
London, and Dr. Walter Jones of the Medical School, are to carry out a joint
research on the relation between the nucleins and nucleo-proteids.
The two
scientists expect to make valuable discoveries in this new field by means of the
polariscope.
The Lawrence Memorial Association held a meeting in McCoy Hall on Al ay
4th. An illustrated lecture on "Settlements" was delivered by Dr. William H.
Tolman, director of the American Institute of Social Service, and an address
was made by Mrs. Vladimir G. Sinikhovitch, director of the Greenwich House,
New York.

THE PHI BETA KAPPA ELECTIONS AND BANQUET.
T the annual meeting of the Maryland Alpha Chapter of the Phi Beta

4

Kappa Fraternity, held on April 22nd, the following men were elected to
membership in the Society:—
Graduate Students: G. 0. Berg, T. C. Foote, F. H. Getman, L. G. Horton,
A. Johannsen, R. D. Miller, W. T. Pierce, J. E. Routh, Jr., A. W. Smith.
Candidates for A. B.: James Wallace Bryan, John Coffey Hildt, Robert
Sampson Lanier, William Urwick Murkland, Joseph Tate Smith, G. Drayton
Strayer.
The following officers were elected: President, Prof. A. Marshall Elliott:
Vice-president, Prof. Paul Haupt; Treasurer, Dr. C. Carroll Marden ; Secretary, Dr. J. Elliott Gilpin.
The annual banquet was held on the 1st of May, in the Donovan Room,
McCoy Hall. The speeches were excellent, that of President Remsen being of
especial interest to, the members of the University. He responded to the toast,
"Our University." After a few words about the million-dollar fund, Dr. Remsen said that the University expects to put up at Homewood, not "palaces," but
buildings plain, imposing and of good architectural style ; that the University will
move out to Homewood as a whole, not in parts; that the project of having an
athletic 'field at Homewood before the University is built up there is impracticable, as no part of the estate is accessible for exhibition purposes.
Professor Perrin, of Yale, spoke of the importance of Phi Beta Kappa in
Philosophical life ; Mr. 'Bonaparte spoke of the good influence of Phi Beta Kappa
in political life.
"Goo! goo!" said the baby as he stuck his finger in his father's old pipe.
—Widow.

THE NEWS LETTER.
THE LAWRENCE HOUSE CONCERT.

t

li E, second annual joint concert by the Woman's College and Johns Hopkins University Musical Clubs will be given in McCoy Hall, on Saturday, May 9th. The performance is for the benefit of the Lawrence House
Social Settlement, and it is hoped that the student body will be sufficiently interested in this work to aid in the success of the concert.
This sort of work in the lower sections of the city is from its very nature
such as to gain but little publicity, and it may be of interest to note briefly a few
of the salient facts in regard to the methods employed in uplifting and bettering the conditions of the poorer classes.
In order to be in touch with the people among whom the work is to be acThis
complished, a house has been purchased on West Lombard Street.
house has been made as attractive and home-like as is possible under such conditions. Classes have been organized, which meet regularly. Many of these
classes have formed themselves into clubs with officers and definite exercises for
each night. As far as possible, the growing boys are given some knowledge of
parliamentary law and by contact with men of training and culture are gradually
led to form standards of conduct, which in many cases have changed the drift of
their lives. The girls are taught needlework and practical housekeeping, and
every helpful influence is thrown around them.
The classes are under the supervision of Miss Alice E. Robbins, who has
learned through practical experience in the slums of New York and London,
how to grapple with the many problems that are being continually presented.
The management of the settlement is vested in a board of managers, of which
M r. Robert Garrett, a former student of this university, is president. Associated
with him are representatives from the various colleges of the city and others interested in the welfare of the poorer classes.
This is a summary of the general idea of the settlement and it must be seen
how vital the work is. The expenses are met through voluntary subscriptions,
and the success of the concert means that one of the chief sources of revenue will
not be curtailed. This statement should be a sufficient appeal to those of philanthropic mind, while a mention of the attractiveness of the programme should
insure the presence of all others. There need be no comment made concerning
the members of the Woman's College Glee and Mandolin Club, for they are
known to all. The quartet from the Medical School will have some new songs,
which should cheer even the most melancholy. Arrangements to hold an informal reception at the close of the concert are under consideration by the committee in charge.

THE NEWS LETTER.

13

ATHLETICS.
LACROSSE.
Hopkins 17—Lehigh 4.
In a game that abounded in all sorts of playing- gi )0(1, bad and indifferent—
the University twelve defeated the Lehigh team on April 26th, in a contest which
was more interesting than the one-sided score-17 to 4—would indicate.
Both teams started off with a rush, and at an early stage it looked as if the
visitors were going to make the 'Varsity team play hard in order to win. They
shot two goals in rapid succession, but their joy was short lived, for after ten
minutes of play the superior skill and endurance of Hopkins became evident,
and the "rooters" were kept busy counting up the score.
Lehigh played a
Plucky game throughout, but they were clearly outclassed by the superior playing
of the University men.
Captain I,attig and George R. Bailey were the star players for the visitors.
Lattig did as fine individual playing as anyone on either side, and to the manner
in which he handled his men is largely due the fact that Lehigh scored her goals,
two of which he himself shot.
Bailey is a Baltimore boy, and for several
years was prominent in athletics in this city. IIis work at point spoiled many
good plays of Hopkins, which might have resulted in more goals.
For Hopkins, Captain Straus, Putts, Bernheim, Matthai and Schmeisser did
especially fine work, although every man on the team deserves credit for so decisive a victory.
One of the prettiest plays that has been seen this season occurred in the first
half. The ball was near Hopkins goal when Schmeisser made a pretty catch and
threw the ball far down the field to Tough. The ball was then rapidly passed
to Matthai, Bird, Dill, Bernheim and Putts, who threw goal. The ball had come
all the way from point to goal without Lehigh being able to break the play.

Hopkins 6—Swarthmore 4.
Y defeating the Swarthmore lacrosse team, 6 to 4, on their home grounds
last Saturday, the Johns Hopkins twelve remains champions of the Intercollegiate League for another year. The game was one of the hardest
fought that has ever been witnessed upon a lacrosse field, and Hopkins did not
clinch it until within the last two minutes of the second half.
A very gratifying feature of the game was the presence of so many Hopkins rooters on the field, and the yelling of friendly voices greatly encouraged
the University men to victory. While not all of the rooters were Baltimoreans,
a large number did go from this city, and the character of the game was a sufficient reward. Many sympathizers went over from Philadelphia and Wilmington,
and waved the black and blue flags as proudly as if Baltimore was their home.

§

14

THE NEWS LETTER.

Every man on the team did his best and covered himself with glory, so that
it is hard to say who deserves the most credit. Foster was probably the most
prominent man on the field. He appeared to be everywhere at once. Whenever a man was blocked or a ball passed, "Fred"was right on hand to do the work.
During most of the game he was on the attack, but owing to the dropping out
of a Swarthmore man, who was slightly injured, and the consequent dropping
of a Hopkins player, he was moved down to the defense.
P. Straus at goal made some remarkable stops. Time and again the ball
came flying toward him, and time and again did he succeed in keeping it from
going between the posts. In the early part of the game he had chances enough to
shake any goal-keeper's nerve. Four stops, three of which were quite difficult,
was what Straus was called upon to do within less than three minutes.
"Billy" Bird was once more among the foremost of the players. His beautiful catching and accurate throwing, especially in the second half, when he let
himself out, did much in keeping the ball in the enemy's territory. The body
checking and heady playing of Matthai and Tough were very effective in breaking up the plays of Swarthmore.
Captain Henry Straus, Schmeisser and Blanck, were the bulwark, as usual,
for the defense, and Custis also did well. Of the attack men, Rosenheim did
splendid work. He played his position like an old hand, and it was due to his
headiness that the last goal was scored. When Bernheim was so well covered
by his opponent that he could not take the ball when passed to him by Bird,
Rosenheim backed him up beautifully and threw goal, thus clinching the victory
for Hopkins.
Putts again distinguished himself by throwing four of the
six goals.
For Swarthmore, the defense put up the best game. In fact, if their attack
had been as strong as their defense, the story might have been different. It is
a significant fact that all of Hopkins's points were made in the east goal, where
the sun was in the face of the defense men. Whenever they changed, the team
could do absolutely nothing in the way of scoring.
Captain Beans, who played in-home, is probably the best player Swarthmore
has had in years. His passing and body checking were excellent, and his throwing was faultless. His record was almost equal to that of Putts, as he scored
three of the four goals made by his team.
At no time during the game wm Swarthmore in the lead. Hopkins threw
the first goal, but her opponents scored shortly afterwards. The 'Varsity succeeded in making two more goals before Swarthmore made one, but before long
the score was again tied. Just after Hopkins made her fourth goal, Swarthmore
repeated the performance. At last, just before the end of the first half, the
University team drew away from its rivals, and the half ended 5 to 4.
Not
another goal was scored by either side until within the last two minutes of the
game, when Rosenheim clinched the victory.

THE NEWS LETTER.

TRACK TEAM.

t

HE Relay Team returned home from the University of Pennsylvania games.
of April 25th, without the customary banner, it is true, but with a feeling
of satisfaction at having made a very Creditable showing in the race for
the "Middle States Championship.- A victory was scarcely to be expected, although hoped for ; but the general opinion prevailed that second place in first
class company is more desirable than first place in second class company.
Owing to a heavy track, caused by improvements that are being made, the time
for all events was somewhat slow, but Hopkins was especially handicapt)ed by
the fact that the race was run in a different direction from that which our runners had been accustomed to, the men thus being compelled to make the turns to
the right, instead of to the left.
The Middle States championship relay race was the nineteenth event. Freese
started for Hopkins, and finished third. Hoffman was the next man, and by good
running pulled up to second place, with Bucknell a good distance in the lead.
England ran third, and made the distance between Bucknell and Hopkins' still
smaller. Tootle was the last man. He ran a beautiful race, closing up the
gap splendidly and finished a close second. Dickinson came in third. BUcknell's
time was 3 minutes, :37 2-5 seconds.
In the high jump, Dr. Geo. B. Scholl tied with a Syracuse man for second
place at 5 feet, 10 inches, and won the toss of the coin.

It is scarcely necessary to account for the absence of news in this issue concerning the Dual Meet with Virginia. As THE NMS-LETTER goes to press
some days before the meet, it is impossible to give an account of the games, and
at the same time it is inadvisable to forecast any events, as all the results will be
known when this issue appears.

ALUMNI NOTES.
James Alfred Kennard, '9S, will he married to Miss Margaret Ridgeley, on
June 3rd.
W. S. Weedon, Ph. D., '02, visited the university on Monday.
Dr. Florence Bascom, '93, who has been associate professor of geology at
Bryn Mawr, has been appointed professor. Her assistant will he Dr. Benjamin
L. Miller, who received his degree at the university last February.
Dr. Councilman, who was assistant professor of pathology at the university
for several years, and who is now professor of pathology at the Harvard Medical
School, has announced his discovery of the small-pox germ.

THE NEWS LETTER.
George S. Brown, '93, was elected to the Second Branch of the City Council
for the Fourth District, on Tuesday. Though Mr. Brown was not backed by
the Democratic organization, he received a larger majority than any of the other
successful candidates.
Alfred W. Bruton, one of the best known and most popular members of
the class of 1901, met death by drowning in the Charles River, Massachusetts,
on last Friday afternoon. Along with a companion, he was canoeing, when a
gust of wind struck the canoe, overturning it, and Bruton was drowned before
help could reach him. Bruton was a student at Boston Tech., and would have
received his degree in Engineering in June. During his three years at the University he played on the football and lacrosse teams,and was one of the best players
at Hopkins. Almost all the members of the athletic teams from 1898 to 1901,
as well as many students, were present at the funeral services, which took place
on Monday afternoon.
At a meeting of the Athletic Association, held on Monday morning, the following resolutions were adopted:
Whereas, It has pleased an all-wise Providence to remove from our midst
our friend and fellow-student, ALFRED WILLIAM BRUTON., and
Whereas, He was a prominent member of the Johns Hopkins Athletic Association, and had endeared himself to all of us by his manly qualities and friend'ship, therefore,
BE rr RE;soLvED, That we, the members of the Johns Hopkins Athletic Association, mourn his loss and extend our deepest sympathy to his bereaved family,
and be it
RESOLVED, That a copy of these resolutions be spread upon the minutes of
the Athletic. Board of the Johns Hopkins Athletic Association, published in
THE NEws-I,ErrER, and a copy be sent to the family.
EDWARD RENO UF,
HENRY A. CONVERSE,
R. CURZON HOFFMAN, JR.
For the Athletic Association.

THE NEWS-LETTER.
VOL. VII.

MAY 7, 1903.

No. 14.

THE GULF BIOLOGICAL STATION.

t

HE want of a biological station on the Gulf of Mexico has long been felt
by American biologists. Until recently no laboratory for the study of
marine biology existed south of Beaufort, North Carolina, although
our southern waters are extremely rich in animal and plant life. So attractive
have been the reports of visitors to the Gulf coast, that a strong desire for a
permanent station has been created, and the United States Fish Commission
has for several years been contemplating the advisableness of gratifying it by
erecting a laboratory on the Florida coast. At present also, the naturalists of
the country are interested in an independent project to establish a station on
the Tortugas. Both of these enterprises have been anticipated by the inauguration of the "Gulf Biologic Station," by the State of Louisiana.
The Louisiana station is located in the south-western extremity of Cameron
Parish, on a point where the Calcasieu River opens into the Gulf. It is about
a day's sail from Galveston, Texas, and 280 miles from New Orleans. The
town of Cameron, two miles inland from the laboratory, is a small settlement
of 150 people. The isolation which is thus secured is one of the summer needs
of the biologist, who, during this period, must be freed from the conventions of
civilized life.
The environment of Cameron is conducive to work—apparently there is
nothing else to do. Northward, east and west, extend the alluvial plains, in
regions thickly wooded, but often bounded only by the horizon. The local
'mango' gives these stretches of shere flatness, somewhat of a roughened edge,
while here and there a decided nick is produced in the sky by a clump of larger
trees. The vastness of these plains gives one the feeling of being alone in a
great solitude. Surely this is the place where that strange desire which many
men feel at sometime of their lives—to shout and not be heard—can be gratified.
Even here disappointment lies in wait. A shout would startle the cattle
cropping peacefully the miles of pasture; they would cock their ears and look
with surprise in the direction of the noise. Some of the more inquisitive ones
would start off at a lively canter, kicking up their hind legs and prancing as
only cows with glad hearts can. In those regions they do not hear a noise
every day of their lives.
South-east, south and south-west, lie the chief interests of the station.
There are the problems in the solution of which Louisiana makes the first state
contribution to research in marine biology.
The campaign begins this summer. The work to be undertaken will include
a study of the best way to develop scientific methods of oyster culture, and a
general biological survey of the Gulf of Mexico. The prevailing South-east
•

2

THE NEWS LETTER.

winds bring to shore many of the pelagic forms with which the Gulf stream is
alive, but the whole mountain does not come to Mahomet.
To meet this difficulty a launch and a sharpy are to be provided. With
these boats extensive dredgings will be made on the flat extending outward from
the coast, and localities will be plotted and marked. Such animals as do not
float ashore or which are too small to be picked up, will be gathered by means
of the surface net which is towed through the water behind a slowly moving
boat. This method of collecting is particularly successful on quiet nights at
high tide. Then the larvx and other small pelagic animals rise to the surface
and can easily be scooped up in large quantities. Their presence in the net is
betrayed by a dim glow. At Beaufort, on very dark still nights, the water is so
crowded with living things, that the course of a boat is marked by flashes of
blinding brilliancy, and in rowing, showers of living sparks drip from the oars.

Besides the Fauna and Flora of the Gulf itself, the student finds much to
interest him on land. Lining the rivers and bayous, are large pecan trees and
live oaks, black and rugged, hut with a tinge of sadness, for the pendant
streamers of the gray Spanish moss lend them the appearance of weeping willows.
The 'mango' grows everywhere, and from its joints spring forth the golden tufts
of the parasitic dodder.
Tropical fruits abound throughout the parish.
Oranges grow in every garden, and lemons, olives, figs and bananas attract no
more attention than our apples and pears,

THE NEWS LETTER.

a

Most attractive of all the land animals are the birds. Wild ducks and
gees live in the marshes whefe they probably feed on the eggs and young of
the diamond back terrapin. Cranes and herons patrol the shores, and the rice
bird hovers about the bushes preparatory to its disastrous flight to the north.
Along the Gulf shore, the jack snipe struts about with nervous jerk, and the
egret, blinding with whiteness, can be seen for miles. As if to set off the beauty
of this bird, the black ominous water-turkey, clumsy of flight, wobbles by, low
on the water. Most conspicuous of all however are the flocks of brown pelican.
These use for a roosting place the great stone jetties that project out to sea
for two miles from the mouth of the Calcasieu. River. Here they sit in straight
dignified rows as though taking a lesson. Suddenly however, they become restless, and in a moment, with legs stretched out stiffly behind, they are off to sea
in an irregular squad, which at last is visible only as a group of small, uncertain
specks. When they are on the verge of disappearing, these specks, momentarily
at rest, suddenly grow larger again, and the return flight begins, this time not in
a squad, but spread out like a thin line of heroes,' until they reach the jetty,
where after considerable disorder, they once more sit motionless in a very
correct row.
The life at a marine laboratory, however remote, is far from dull and anything but conventional. It is too full of activity to be the one and too unusual
to be the other. For the men who spend their vacations at a sea-side station,
work is a source of endless pleasure, and they who can experience the delight of
finding out something new, are amply repaid for all sacrifices. While it sometimes happens that a whole night is 'spent in watching a series of developing
eggs, and that meals are brought to the work table, more often the days pass
with a healthy mixture of indoor and outdoor work. The latter nearly always
means a few hours' run on the launch, a sail—time of return is never mentioned--a walk on the beach, and probably a dip in the surf.
These collecting trips, even when resulting in no particular find, are never
without good effect, for the exertion, the excitement and sometimes the risk call
into play all the powers of body and .mind, and bring about the tingle that
always. accompanies the healthful expenditure of superfluous energy.
Then
too, the community of interests makes good cheer and the air is blue with songs,
stories and puns. Even university professors, tight-laced with dignity, learning
and fame, do not hesitate to smoke a corn-cob pipe and to take off their shoes
and stockings when necessary.. A crowd of biologists coming back from a
moonlight towing would, in a city, be arrested for disturbing the peace.
THE DEBATE WITH NORTH CAROLINA.
GAIN the Universii y of North Carolina has defeated us in debate ; but
the contest was even closer than last year, and the decision of the judges
was not unanimous. Then, too, Hopkins won a partial victory in that
the judges unanimously decided Plaggemeyer the best debater who took part
in the contest. Hopkins lost the debate because the North Carolina team excelled
•

4

4

THE NEWS LETTER.

in logical development and the completeness of their line of argument. In delivery the Hopkins men equalled or excelled their opponents.
The debate was held in Gerrard Hall in the presence of an audience composed largely of university professors and students. Governor Aycock, who
presided, announced the question, read the instructions to the judges, and then
called upon the secretary to announce the first speaker upon the affirmative side.
Mr. Solomon Blum, who opened the debate for Hopkins, was well received, and succeeded in making his points stand out clearly. Mr. S. S. Robins,
a junior at North Carolina, followed with a speech such as one hears upon the
floor of the United States Senate. The speech, which dealt largely with the development of governmental functions and the history of our merchant marine, was
delivered in a masterful manner. When Mr. Plaggemeyer had finished the
next speech for Hopkins, the advantage that Carolina had gained in her first
speech was largely overcome. Mr. R. 0. Everett, a senior, then delivered a
twenty-minute speech in which he still further developed the line of argument laid
down in Carolina's first speech. In the rejoinders the extemporaneous speeches
of Messrs. Blum, Robins and Everett demonstrated the ability of those men to
think quickly and to present their arguments clearly without previous preparation. But Plaggemeyer's rebuttal was by far the most effective speech of the
evening. Plag. was at his best and he carried his audience with him in a way that
surprised even those who have heard him in former debates. When he finished
speaking, it was any one's victory. As it was, the decision proved to be a victory
for Plaggemeyer as well as for the University of North Carolina.
While the judges were deliberating, Governor Aycock responded to the repeated demonstrations of the Carolina students. He said that, in his opinion, the
judges had to decide the old question:—"What happens when an irresistable force
meets an immovable body." During the debate, the Governor said his convictions had been reinforced and his faith destroyed four times that he awaited the
decision of the judges in order that he might know whether he must forsake the
traditions of his childhood, or be permitted to die in the faith.
After the Governor had ceased speaking, the Carolina students in the gallery called for Strayer, the alternate of the Hopkins team, who expressed, on
behalf of the team, their appreciation of the hospitality which they had enjoyed.
When the decision had been announced and congratulations had been exchanged,
a carriage conveyed the Hopkins men to the residence of Professor Gore, where
they were introduced to Governor Aycock, President Venable, the judges of the
debate, the professors and their wives, and many of the Carolina students who
are interested in debating. After they had enjoyed the collation provided, the
team returned to the hotel to get a few hours sleep before starting home. ,
The members of the Johns Hopkins party unite to express high appreciation
of their reception and entertainment at Chapel Hill. They all declare that their
personal acquaintance with the traditional cordiality and hospitality of Dixie
farther South has been most pleasantly enlarged.

l g V its victory over Swarthmore on last Saturday, the University lacrosse
team is once more entitled to the proud distinction of being The Intercollegiate Champions of the United States." Winner of the championship
five times in six years is a record that would be hard to surpass. This year the
honor was not won without the hardest kind of work, and for this reason every
man connected with the team deserves all the more credit. At the beginning
of the season the chances for another championship team seemed slight indeed.
The loss of such lacrosse players as Abercrombie, Briscoe, Bernheim, Sayler, and
Captain Schmeisser seemed too great to be overcome, and predictions were made
that with the material on hand the University could not develop a first class
team for 1903. Nothing daunted, however, .Captain Straus and Coach Abercrombie set to work to develop a team that would stand comparison with those
of former • years. From the beginning the men were impressed with the fact
that steady, consistent work was absolutely necessary. The 1903 championship
banner that will soon be hung in the trophy room bears witness of their success.
Though the Intercollegiate lacrosse season is ended, there are some more
honors that the team is trying for, . On Saturday, the Crescents, the - Athletic

THE NEWS LETTER.
Champions of the United States, will play the University, and without question
the game will be one of the best seen in Baltimore for some time. The Crescents have not forgot their defeat two years ago, and according to report, are
going to bring to Baltimore some of the best lacrosse players in the country. The
University team is just as determined to win, and make the year an unbroken
line of victories.

HE joint concert of the Woman's College and the University Musical
Clubs to be given on Saturday night for the benefit of the Lawrence
House Mission, deserves the support of every Hopkins man. In another
column is given an account of how the mission carries on its work. Clearly an
object more worthy of the united assistance of all cannot be found. Since the
work done by the mission is very great, the opportunity for assisting in this work,
and at the same time being agreeably entertained, should be taken advantage of.
A number of students give practical aid to the mission by taking charge of classes.
However, this is not all that is needed; financial help is absolutely necessary to
continue the work. For this reason, the management hopes to have even a
larger attendance at the concert than last year, when a considerable sum was
turned over.

'l' length, after many months of hard work, the long-suffering editors of the
1903 Hullabaloo are ready to announce what will be the special feature.,
of their book. From their description, this "Hullabaloo" bids fair to be
one of the best and most interesting ever brought out by the students of the
university.
In the first place, the cover will be black and blue, divided diagonally,
with the class flag showing the class colors, olive and white, in one corner.
Another of Brook Levering's allegorical color-pieces is promised. The leader:
will be two in number, a departure from former "Hullabaloos"—the first by W.
W. Willoughby, Ph. D., Associate Professor of Political Science, the second by
Dr. E. L. R. Gould, Chamberlain of New York •City. The peculiarly interesting feature of these leaders is that they are articles in which specialists aro
speaking of their specialty—"talking shop," as it were.
The order of the classes is reversed, the Sub-freshmen coming first and the
Seniors last. In connection with the class lists, there are some amusing drawings
showing the progress from the innocence of the Sub-freshman to the dignity of the
Senior. The fraternity drawing is a striking one by McKee Barclay. The
members of the fraternities not having chapters at the University have been carefully and thoroughly worked up. An excellent idea in connection with Athletics
is that on the page opposite each team picture are the description and personnel
of the team. A complete and detailed list of all the "H's" and "H. A. A.'s"
of
in the university, has for the first time been compiled. As for the "stunts,"

--several pages are devoted to the opinions of the members of the class on things
in general (including "girls") and to the votes of the class on the various qualifications of certain of the members. These begin the "stunts" proper which

However, the features of the book on which the board has worked hardest

have been most sung by University students. This Song Book is the first that
has'ever been published at the Hopkins, and it is hoped that this small beginning
may lead to better things in this line.
It is hoped by the editors that the "Hullabaloo" will be out by the 15th of
May, but this depends on Providence and the printers. In bringing out the
"Hullabaloo" the board has had a trouble with which former boards have not
been afflicted—they have had to solicit their advertisements, instead of the publisher taking charge of this side of the book. However, by the remarkable
push and ability of "Billy" Bird, this financially important feature has been excellently handled. In conclusion it is only necessary to say that the 1903 "Hullabaloo" will undoubtedly be a credit to Lanier, Tootle and the other members
of the editorial staff.

THE NEWS LETTER.
BALTIMORE'S NEXT MAYOR.

OHNS HOPKINS has developed her first mayor. She has entertained a
good many mayors at her publiic gatherings in the past, but never one of
her own. When the Hon. Robert M. McLane makes his bow at the
next commencement exercises, the distinguished assembly will be receiving the
salute of the member of the class of 1887. His salute will doubtless be returned
in the proper spirit.
Baltimore's mayor-elect prepared at Mr. Marston's School, entering the University in the Fall of 1884. He took the classical course, and during his entire
undergraduate career was a leader in his classes. From his Freshman year until
his graduation, Mr. McLane held honorary scholarships, and graduated with high
honors. He was, however, no "grind," but had the happy faculty of getting at
the gist of his studies without much work. In the eighties there were not so
many athletic teams as there are to-day, and Baltimore's mayor went for nothing
more strenuous than tennis, at which game he was a player of more than ordinary
ability. A gentleman who was at the University with Mr. McLane, says that he
enjoyed a good joke, and always had a ready line of stories, which he told in a
most entertaining manner. He was always one of the best dressed men about the
University. By many, Mayor McLane is remembered as a 'clean cut, faultlessly
dressed chap, who always had a pleasant smile, and a cheerful word for his companions, but who did not mingle much with them. In those days he cared little
for the society of women, a habit which seems never to have left him.
After leaving the University Mr. McLane followed the usual course of
studies suscribed by the Maryland University's faculty, and became a member of
the Baltimore bar. About four years ago he was elected State's Attorney on the
Democratic ticket. He now leaves the Criminal Court for the City Hall.

TURIN BULL LECTURES 1903 04.

The lectures on the Percy Turnbull Memorial Foundation for the academic
year 1903-04 will be given by Count Angelo de Gubernatis, Professor of Italian
Literature in the University of Rome.
The lectures will be eight or nine in number, and the subject will be the
"Poetry of the Italian Renaissance." The lecturer will speak in French.
Count de Gubernatis is Professor of Italian Literature in the University of
Rome; General Secretary of the Italian Oriental Academy; the author of numerous literary, historical, and dramatic works; Italian correspondent of the
Athenaeum and the Contemporary Review, London, the International Review,
Vermont, and other papers.

UNIVERSITY NOTES.

Dr. L. S. Hulbert, who has bccn ill with typhoid fever, is convalescing.
Dr. A. Marshall Elliott will sail in :June for the other, side, and will spend
the summer abroad.
Dr. Bower, of Washington, delivered a lecture in the Physical Laboratory,
Monday, April 27th, on "Terrestial Magnetism."
Dr. Bower also gave the
students interested in the subject a chance to pursue the actual experiments at
Fort McHenry.
Saturday, May 9th, Dr. Paul Haupt will sail from New York for England,
where he will visit Oxford and Cambridge, after which he will travel in Germany.
At the meeting of the National Academy of Sciences held in Washington,
April 22nd, President Remsen was elected vice-president of the Academy. Prof.
Simon Newcomb was elected foreign secretary to succeed President Remsen.
Prof. W. H. Welch was elected a member of the Academy council.
Dr. Norman MacLeod Harris, associate in bacteriology, has resigned from
the Medical School and has accepted a position as assistant to Dr. Jordan, professor of bacteriology at the University of Chicago.
At the meeting of the Eastern Teachers' Art Association, held in McCoy
Hall, an address of welcome was delivered by Dr. Geo. B. Shaddock. An attractive exhibit of tie work of the school children in several towns and cities
throughout the country was arranged in the main hall. The drawings called
forth much favorable comment from visitors.
Dr. Florence R. Sabin, an assistant in anatomy at the Medical School, has
won the prize of $1,000. offered two years ago by the Association for the Promotion of Scientific Research by Women. Dr. Sabin's paper is on the "Origin
of the Lymphatic System." Dr. Sabin received her M. D. at the Hopkins in 1900.
During her course she held the fellowship in anatomy, and after her graduation
she was appointed instructor. Recently, she was offered the professorship of
anatomy at the Woman's Medical College in London, but she declined, preferring
her present work at the Hopkins.
At a recent meeting of the American Institute. of Social Service, Mr. Robert
Garrett, Dr. Albert Shaw, and Dr. E. R. L. Gould were appointed members of
the American committee which is to co-operate with the sociological workers of
the other countries in the International Housing Congress, to be held in Paris,
from July to November next. The congress is to be under the patronage of the
French government. It will discuss the importance of inaugurating preventive
measures against the spread of tuberculosis and alcoholism..
At the meeting of the .M edical and Chirurgical Faculty, papers were read
by Drs. William H. Welch and Henry B. Jacobs. Dr. Welch spoke chiefly about
the methods employed in New York for the prevention of tuberculosis. Dr.
Jacobs read a paper on "Our Need of a Mountain Sanitarium for Indigent
Consumptives." Other papers were read by the following Hopkins men: Drs.
W. S. Baer, T. R. Brown, H. O. Reik and S. R. Hirshberg. Professor R. W.
Wood also delivered a lecture on "Colored Photography."

along the line laid down in his "Principles of Inorganic Chemistry," published
several months ago.
Dr. Norman MacD. Harris, associate in bacteriology, has revised and edited
an American edition of the "Manual of Bacteriology," by Doctors Muir and
Ritchie. The book is published by the Macmillian Co.
Dr. Gamgee, the distinguished professor of physiology at Owens College,
London, and Dr. Walter Jones of the Medical School, are to carry out a joint
research on the relation between the nucleins and nucleo-proteids.
The two
scientists expect to make valuable discoveries in this new field by means of the
polariscope.

was made by Mrs. Vladimir G. Sinikhovitch, director of the Greenwich House,

The following officers were elected: President, Prof. A. Marshall Elliott:
Vice-president, Prof. Paul Haupt; Treasurer, Dr. C. Carroll Marden ; Secretary, Dr. J. Elliott Gilpin.
The annual banquet was held on the 1st of May, in the Donovan Room,
McCoy Hall. The speeches were excellent, that of President Remsen being of
especial interest to, the members of the University. He responded to the toast,
"Our University." After a few words about the million-dollar fund, Dr. Remsen said that the University expects to put up at Homewood, not "palaces," but
buildings plain, imposing and of good architectural style ; that the University will
move out to Homewood as a whole, not in parts; that the project of having an
athletic 'field at Homewood before the University is built up there is impracticable, as no part of the estate is accessible for exhibition purposes.
Professor Perrin, of Yale, spoke of the importance of Phi Beta Kappa in
Philosophical life ; Mr. 'Bonaparte spoke of the good influence of Phi Beta Kappa
in political life.

THE NEWS LETTER.
THE LAWRENCE HOUSE CONCERT.

t

li E, second annual joint concert by the Woman's College and Johns Hopkins University Musical Clubs will be given in McCoy Hall, on Saturday, May 9th. The performance is for the benefit of the Lawrence House
Social Settlement, and it is hoped that the student body will be sufficiently interested in this work to aid in the success of the concert.
This sort of work in the lower sections of the city is from its very nature
such as to gain but little publicity, and it may be of interest to note briefly a few
of the salient facts in regard to the methods employed in uplifting and bettering the conditions of the poorer classes.
In order to be in touch with the people among whom the work is to be acThis
complished, a house has been purchased on West Lombard Street.
house has been made as attractive and home-like as is possible under such conditions. Classes have been organized, which meet regularly. Many of these
classes have formed themselves into clubs with officers and definite exercises for
each night. As far as possible, the growing boys are given some knowledge of
parliamentary law and by contact with men of training and culture are gradually
led to form standards of conduct, which in many cases have changed the drift of
their lives. The girls are taught needlework and practical housekeeping, and
every helpful influence is thrown around them.
The classes are under the supervision of Miss Alice E. Robbins, who has
learned through practical experience in the slums of New York and London,
how to grapple with the many problems that are being continually presented.
The management of the settlement is vested in a board of managers, of which
M r. Robert Garrett, a former student of this university, is president. Associated
with him are representatives from the various colleges of the city and others interested in the welfare of the poorer classes.
This is a summary of the general idea of the settlement and it must be seen
how vital the work is. The expenses are met through voluntary subscriptions,
and the success of the concert means that one of the chief sources of revenue will
not be curtailed. This statement should be a sufficient appeal to those of philanthropic mind, while a mention of the attractiveness of the programme should
insure the presence of all others. There need be no comment made concerning
the members of the Woman's College Glee and Mandolin Club, for they are
known to all. The quartet from the Medical School will have some new songs,
which should cheer even the most melancholy. Arrangements to hold an informal reception at the close of the concert are under consideration by the committee in charge.

ATHLETICS.
LACROSSE.
Hopkins 17—Lehigh 4.
In a game that abounded in all sorts of playing- gi )0(1, bad and indifferent—
the University twelve defeated the Lehigh team on April 26th, in a contest which
was more interesting than the one-sided score-17 to 4—would indicate.
Both teams started off with a rush, and at an early stage it looked as if the
visitors were going to make the 'Varsity team play hard in order to win. They
shot two goals in rapid succession, but their joy was short lived, for after ten
minutes of play the superior skill and endurance of Hopkins became evident,
and the "rooters" were kept busy counting up the score.
Lehigh played a
Plucky game throughout, but they were clearly outclassed by the superior playing
of the University men.
Captain I,attig and George R. Bailey were the star players for the visitors.
Lattig did as fine individual playing as anyone on either side, and to the manner
in which he handled his men is largely due the fact that Lehigh scored her goals,
two of which he himself shot.
Bailey is a Baltimore boy, and for several
years was prominent in athletics in this city. IIis work at point spoiled many
good plays of Hopkins, which might have resulted in more goals.
For Hopkins, Captain Straus, Putts, Bernheim, Matthai and Schmeisser did
especially fine work, although every man on the team deserves credit for so decisive a victory.
One of the prettiest plays that has been seen this season occurred in the first
half. The ball was near Hopkins goal when Schmeisser made a pretty catch and
threw the ball far down the field to Tough. The ball was then rapidly passed
to Matthai, Bird, Dill, Bernheim and Putts, who threw goal. The ball had come
all the way from point to goal without Lehigh being able to break the play.

Hopkins 6—Swarthmore 4.
Y defeating the Swarthmore lacrosse team, 6 to 4, on their home grounds
last Saturday, the Johns Hopkins twelve remains champions of the Intercollegiate League for another year. The game was one of the hardest
fought that has ever been witnessed upon a lacrosse field, and Hopkins did not
clinch it until within the last two minutes of the second half.
A very gratifying feature of the game was the presence of so many Hopkins rooters on the field, and the yelling of friendly voices greatly encouraged
the University men to victory. While not all of the rooters were Baltimoreans,
a large number did go from this city, and the character of the game was a sufficient reward. Many sympathizers went over from Philadelphia and Wilmington,
and waved the black and blue flags as proudly as if Baltimore was their home.

§

14

THE NEWS LETTER.

Every man on the team did his best and covered himself with glory, so that
it is hard to say who deserves the most credit. Foster was probably the most
prominent man on the field. He appeared to be everywhere at once. Whenever a man was blocked or a ball passed, "Fred"was right on hand to do the work.
During most of the game he was on the attack, but owing to the dropping out
of a Swarthmore man, who was slightly injured, and the consequent dropping
of a Hopkins player, he was moved down to the defense.
P. Straus at goal made some remarkable stops. Time and again the ball
came flying toward him, and time and again did he succeed in keeping it from
going between the posts. In the early part of the game he had chances enough to
shake any goal-keeper's nerve. Four stops, three of which were quite difficult,
was what Straus was called upon to do within less than three minutes.
"Billy" Bird was once more among the foremost of the players. His beautiful catching and accurate throwing, especially in the second half, when he let
himself out, did much in keeping the ball in the enemy's territory. The body
checking and heady playing of Matthai and Tough were very effective in breaking up the plays of Swarthmore.
Captain Henry Straus, Schmeisser and Blanck, were the bulwark, as usual,
for the defense, and Custis also did well. Of the attack men, Rosenheim did
splendid work. He played his position like an old hand, and it was due to his
headiness that the last goal was scored. When Bernheim was so well covered
by his opponent that he could not take the ball when passed to him by Bird,
Rosenheim backed him up beautifully and threw goal, thus clinching the victory
for Hopkins.
Putts again distinguished himself by throwing four of the
six goals.
For Swarthmore, the defense put up the best game. In fact, if their attack
had been as strong as their defense, the story might have been different. It is
a significant fact that all of Hopkins's points were made in the east goal, where
the sun was in the face of the defense men. Whenever they changed, the team
could do absolutely nothing in the way of scoring.
Captain Beans, who played in-home, is probably the best player Swarthmore
has had in years. His passing and body checking were excellent, and his throwing was faultless. His record was almost equal to that of Putts, as he scored
three of the four goals made by his team.
At no time during the game wm Swarthmore in the lead. Hopkins threw
the first goal, but her opponents scored shortly afterwards. The 'Varsity succeeded in making two more goals before Swarthmore made one, but before long
the score was again tied. Just after Hopkins made her fourth goal, Swarthmore
repeated the performance. At last, just before the end of the first half, the
University team drew away from its rivals, and the half ended 5 to 4.
Not
another goal was scored by either side until within the last two minutes of the
game, when Rosenheim clinched the victory.

TRACK TEAM.

t

HE Relay Team returned home from the University of Pennsylvania games.
of April 25th, without the customary banner, it is true, but with a feeling
of satisfaction at having made a very Creditable showing in the race for
the "Middle States Championship.- A victory was scarcely to be expected, although hoped for ; but the general opinion prevailed that second place in first
class company is more desirable than first place in second class company.
Owing to a heavy track, caused by improvements that are being made, the time
for all events was somewhat slow, but Hopkins was especially handicapt)ed by
the fact that the race was run in a different direction from that which our runners had been accustomed to, the men thus being compelled to make the turns to
the right, instead of to the left.
The Middle States championship relay race was the nineteenth event. Freese
started for Hopkins, and finished third. Hoffman was the next man, and by good
running pulled up to second place, with Bucknell a good distance in the lead.
England ran third, and made the distance between Bucknell and Hopkins' still
smaller. Tootle was the last man. He ran a beautiful race, closing up the
gap splendidly and finished a close second. Dickinson came in third. BUcknell's
time was 3 minutes, :37 2-5 seconds.
In the high jump, Dr. Geo. B. Scholl tied with a Syracuse man for second
place at 5 feet, 10 inches, and won the toss of the coin.

It is scarcely necessary to account for the absence of news in this issue concerning the Dual Meet with Virginia. As THE NMS-LETTER goes to press
some days before the meet, it is impossible to give an account of the games, and
at the same time it is inadvisable to forecast any events, as all the results will be
known when this issue appears.

ALUMNI NOTES.
James Alfred Kennard, '9S, will he married to Miss Margaret Ridgeley, on
June 3rd.
W. S. Weedon, Ph. D., '02, visited the university on Monday.
Dr. Florence Bascom, '93, who has been associate professor of geology at
Bryn Mawr, has been appointed professor. Her assistant will he Dr. Benjamin
L. Miller, who received his degree at the university last February.
Dr. Councilman, who was assistant professor of pathology at the university
for several years, and who is now professor of pathology at the Harvard Medical
School, has announced his discovery of the small-pox germ.

THE NEWS LETTER.
George S. Brown, '93, was elected to the Second Branch of the City Council
for the Fourth District, on Tuesday. Though Mr. Brown was not backed by
the Democratic organization, he received a larger majority than any of the other
successful candidates.
Alfred W. Bruton, one of the best known and most popular members of
the class of 1901, met death by drowning in the Charles River, Massachusetts,
on last Friday afternoon. Along with a companion, he was canoeing, when a
gust of wind struck the canoe, overturning it, and Bruton was drowned before
help could reach him. Bruton was a student at Boston Tech., and would have
received his degree in Engineering in June. During his three years at the University he played on the football and lacrosse teams,and was one of the best players
at Hopkins. Almost all the members of the athletic teams from 1898 to 1901,
as well as many students, were present at the funeral services, which took place
on Monday afternoon.
At a meeting of the Athletic Association, held on Monday morning, the following resolutions were adopted:
Whereas, It has pleased an all-wise Providence to remove from our midst
our friend and fellow-student, ALFRED WILLIAM BRUTON., and
Whereas, He was a prominent member of the Johns Hopkins Athletic Association, and had endeared himself to all of us by his manly qualities and friend'ship, therefore,
BE rr RE;soLvED, That we, the members of the Johns Hopkins Athletic Association, mourn his loss and extend our deepest sympathy to his bereaved family,
and be it
RESOLVED, That a copy of these resolutions be spread upon the minutes of
the Athletic. Board of the Johns Hopkins Athletic Association, published in
THE NEws-I,ErrER, and a copy be sent to the family.
EDWARD RENO UF,
HENRY A. CONVERSE,
R. CURZON HOFFMAN, JR.
For the Athletic Association.
